Hands down, one of the best games of all time.
If you love creativity, creation, drama, and life, this game is for you! Half the time I spend hours simply creating sims and its so fun. Bringing a human being to life of your own creation and descending them into a wacky world where they can have children, work a job, or do so much more if you have expansion packs (which I highly recommend). This game is so funny and enjoyable. The expansion packs have brought a world of drama into my sims lives as now some have become vampires, werewolves, or witches! Additionally, I love the normal (non-paranormal) aspects as well. Getting to raise a family and design your own home, getting to see your family trees expand and even interact with other families you have made is a beautiful sight to see. 
Some things to note: This game does take time if you want things to be completely in your control. Whether its creating a sim, building a home, ensuring that each sim in your household grows the skills you want them to have, all takes time and care. But if this doesn't interest you, then get a little wild with it, let your sims do their own thing. That's what makes this game amazing is that you can do whatever you want and whenever you want. 
For newcomers, the game may seem bland at first, but even without expansions packs there are ways to have fun. I strongly recommend using cheats if your looking for a sandbox-based gameplay, (you can easily find them on the web) and the Devs even support the use of cheats as well because they just want people to have fun. 
Be creative, go crazy, and let loose! If this game ever feels stressful because your trying to make the perfect family, then I'd recommend letting go of control and watching your sims grow a bit with small nudges in the right directions. Sometimes complete control is not always necessary for the right outcomes in this game. 
Hope this review finds you all well, cheers!

The Sims‚Ñ¢ 4 continues the franchise‚Äôs legacy as one of the most entertaining and creative life-simulation sandboxes out there. Whether you enjoy building dream homes, micromanaging daily routines, or creating over-the-top stories filled with chaos, the game gives you plenty of freedom to play your way.

What The Sims‚Ñ¢ 4 Does Well:

Powerful Build/Buy Mode: Building houses is incredibly intuitive thanks to flexible tools, room templates, and a massive variety of design elements. Even beginners can create impressive homes quickly.

Create-a-Sim (CAS): The character creator is detailed and easy to use. You can sculpt facial features, pick from many outfits, and give Sims unique personalities and aspirations.

Player Creativity: The game shines most as a creativity engine. You can tell stories, recreate real-life people, or make absurd scenarios‚Äîwhatever fits your style.

Modding Community: An active modding scene adds tons of content, gameplay features, and visual improvements that keep the experience fresh.

Where It Falls Short:

Base Game Feels Light: Without DLC, the gameplay loop can start to feel repetitive. Many features fans expect (e.g., deeper personalities or expanded activities) require expansion packs.

Performance & Bugs: While improved over time, occasional bugs and odd Sim behaviors still appear.

Expensive DLC Model: The sheer amount of paid add-ons can be overwhelming and pricey.

Conclusion:
The Sims‚Ñ¢ 4 is a fun, flexible sandbox perfect for creativity, storytelling, and casual gameplay. While the base game has limitations, especially without add-ons, it still offers countless hours of entertainment‚Äîespecially for fans of life sims and open-ended play. If you enjoy building or crafting character-driven stories, this game is absolutely worth trying.

The game is not without its flaws. The biggest drawback is the lack of an open world. Moving between any two lots (including from home to a neighbor's house or the gym) requires a loading screen. This breaks the immersion and makes the worlds feel small and segmented.
